title: Unilever bosses pledge to cut use of new plastic by 50 PER CENT in massive drive against pollution
text:
Unilever has pledged to cut its use of ‘virgin plastic’ in half to 350,000 tons a year in a landmark move against waste and pollution.

The company, whose brands include Domestos, Dove, Hellmann’s and Marmite, will reduce the total used in bottles and cartons from around 700,000 tons over the next six years. It will include a switch to refillable bottles.

Anglo-Dutch giant Unilever, which makes more than 400 products, claims it is the first global consumer goods company to commit to an absolute reduction in the use of plastics.

Chief executive Alan Jope said: ‘We are not against plastic. We think it plays an important role in society. But the place for plastic is not in the environment.’

Unilever will reduce the total used in bottles and cartons from around 700,000 tons over the next six years

However, critics say Unilever will increase the use of recycled plastic by up to 250,000 tons a year, which means a net reduction of only 100,000 tons.

Campaign group A Plastic Planet said the firm was ‘showing real intent to turn off the plastic tap’. But it added: ‘Unilever is one of the top five polluters. We want to see them being more ambitious by reducing overall plastic by 50 per cent.’

Unilever said it would invest in having more reusable or refillable packs for its products as well as cutting the amount of plastic used in its packaged goods. It said that it would also use alternative wrappings or, where possible, put goods ‘naked’ on the shelf.

The Anglo-Dutch giant, whose brands include Domestos, claims it is the first global consumer goods company to commit to an absolute reduction in the use of plastics

It said the greater use of concentrates, for example in washing liquids and cleaners, reduced the use of plastics by 75 per cent. It also highlighted initiatives such as its introduction of shampoo bars, cardboard wrapped deodorant sticks and bamboo toothbrushes.

Critics say Unilever will increase the use of recycled plastic by up to 250,000 tons a year, which means a net reduction of only 100,000 tons. One of Unilevers brands is Marmite

The switch to pouches of laundry liquid and cleaning fluids can create problems. Just last week, the makers of Dettol were warned over bogus plastic reduction claims following the introduction of pouches alongside refillable bottles.

The problem relates to the fact that many councils do not allow householders to put the pouches, which are made of a complex mix of materials, into recycling bins, while they do collect the plastic bottles.

Mr Jope added: 'Our starting point has to be design, reducing the amount of plastic we use, and then making sure that what we do use increasingly comes from recycled sources.

‘We are also committed to ensuring all our plastic packaging is reusable, recyclable or compostable.’

Paula Chin, sustainable materials specialist at WWF UK, said: ‘Unilever’s ambition to slash their plastic usage and to process more plastic than it sells is a welcome step.

‘We need to see more businesses, producers and governments all taking greater responsibility.

‘The natural world isn’t a luxury - it is our life support system, and we must act now to protect it, before it’s too late.’
